speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us—maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since the beginning of the pandemic, we have taken forceful actions to provide relief and stability, to ensure that the recovery will be as strong as possible, and to limit lasting damage to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today my colleagues on the Federal Open Market Committee and I reaffirmed our commitment to support the economy in this challenging time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Economic activity has continued to recover from its depressed second-quarter level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The reopening of the economy led to a rapid rebound in activity, and real GDP rose at an annual rate of 33 percent in the third quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In recent months, however, the pace of improvement has moderated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Household spending on goods, especially durable goods, has been strong and has moved above its pre-pandemic level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, spending on services remains low, largely due to ongoing weakness in sectors that typically require people to gather closely, including travel and hospitality.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The overall rebound in household spending owes, in part, to federal stimulus payments and expanded unemployment benefits, which provided essential support to many families and individuals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The housing sector has fully recovered from the downturn, supported in part by low mortgage interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Business investment has also picked up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, overall economic activity remains well below its level before the pandemic, and the path ahead remains highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the labor market, roughly half of the 22 million jobs that were lost in March and April have been regained, as many people were able to return to work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As with overall economic activity, the pace of improvement in the labor market has moderated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate declined over the past five months but remained elevated at 7.9 percent as of September.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: November 5, 2020 Although we welcome this progress, we will not lose sight of the millions of Americans who Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL remain out of work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been hardest hit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, the high level of joblessness has been especially severe for lower-wage workers in the services sector, for women, and for African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic dislocation has upended many lives and created great uncertainty about the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The pandemic has also left a significant imprint on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Following large declines in the spring, consumer prices picked up over the summer, in part reflecting a rise in durable goods prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: However, for those sectors that have been most affected by the pandemic, prices remain particularly soft.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, on a 12-month basis, inflation remains below our 2 percent longer-run objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we have emphasized throughout the pandemic, the outlook for the economy is extraordinarily uncertain and will depend in large part on the success of efforts to keep the virus in check.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The recent rise in new COVID-19 cases, both here in the United States and abroad, is particularly concerning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of us have a role to play in our nation’s response to the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Following the advice of public health professionals to keep appropriate social distances and to wear masks in public will help get the economy back to full strength.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A full economic recovery is unlikely until people are confident that it’s safe to reengage in a broad range of activities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Federal Reserve’s response to this crisis has been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As noted in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, we view maximum employment as a “broad-based and inclusive goal.” Our ability to achieve maximum employment in the years ahead depends importantly on November 5, 2020 having longer-term inflation expectations well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we said in September Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL and again today, with inflation running persistently below 2 percent, we will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these employment and inflation outcomes are achieved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With regard to interest rates, we continue to expect that it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee’s assessments of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, over coming months we will continue to increase our holdings of Treasury securities and agency mortgage-backed securities at least at the current pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These asset purchases are intended to sustain smooth market functioning and help foster accommodative financial conditions, thereby supporting the flow of credit to households and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At this meeting, my colleagues and I discussed our asset purchases and the role they are playing in supporting the recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the current pace, our holdings of securities are rising at a substantial rate of $120 billion per month—$80 billion per month of Treasuries and $40 billion per month of agency MBS.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We believe these purchases, along with the very large purchases made to preserve financial stability in the depths of the crisis, have materially eased financial conditions and are providing substantial support to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, we will continue to monitor developments and assess how our ongoing asset purchases can best support our maximum-employment and price-stability objectives as well as market functioning and financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Federal Reserve has also been taking broad and forceful actions to more directly support the flow of credit in the economy for households, for businesses large and small, and for state and local governments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Preserving the flow of credit is essential for mitigating damage to the economy and promoting a robust recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many of our programs rely on emergency lending powers that require the support of the Treasury Department and are available only in very unusual circumstances, such as those we find ourselves in today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These programs serve as a backstop to key credit markets and have helped to restore the flow of credit from private lenders through normal channels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have deployed these lending powers to an unprecedented extent, enabled in large part by financial backing and support from Congress and the Treasury.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When the time comes, after the crisis has passed, we will put these emergency tools back in the toolbox.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I have emphasized before, these are lending powers, not spending powers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed cannot grant money to particular beneficiaries.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can only create programs or facilities with broad-based eligibility to make loans to solvent entities with the expectation that the loans will be repaid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many borrowers are benefiting from these programs, as is the overall economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But for many others, getting a loan that may be difficult to repay may not be the answer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In these cases, direct fiscal support may be needed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Elected officials have the power to tax and spend and to make decisions about where we, as a society, should direct our collective resources.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The fiscal policy actions that have been taken thus far have made a critical difference to families, businesses, and communities across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, the current economic downturn is the most severe in our lifetimes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will take a while to get back to the levels of economic activity and employment that prevailed at the beginning of this year, and it may take continued support from both monetary and fiscal policy to achieve that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’d like to mention a couple of changes that we plan on making to our Summary of Economic Projections beginning in December.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: First, we will release the entire package of SEP materials at the same time that the FOMC statement comes out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Previously, some of these materials were released three weeks after the meeting as part of the minutes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This step will make more information available at the time of our policy announcements, including the distributions of forecasts and how participants judge the uncertainty and risks that attend their projections.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Second, we will add two new graphs that show how the balance of participants’ assessments of uncertainty and risks have evolved over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These changes to the SEP will provide a timely perspective on the risks and uncertainties that surround the modal or baseline projections, thereby highlighting some of the risk-management considerations that are relevant for monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy and to help assure that the recovery from this difficult period will be as robust as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let’s start with February.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In February, we had an economy that was performing well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Then the pandemic hit, and we had a record decline in November 5, 2020 activity in March and April, and then we had a record bounceback in May and June.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so as I Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL think would have been expected and was expected, the pace of improvement from May and June has now moderated, so it’s not unexpected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think if you look at just about anything, you know, for example, the payroll readings, the payroll job gains in May and June were just outsized.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they’re certainly still very large, but they’ve—but the pace of improvement has moderated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s the case for, for all different measures in the labor force—in the labor market, rather.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Another would be claims.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Just about all the data were—showed a big bounceback.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But then, as you would expect, when, when you sort of had people—a lot of people go back to work at once, the pace will moderate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Same thing with economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Most forecasts call for, you know, still a significant growth in the fourth quarter but not at the 33 percent annualized pace that we had in the third quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in a sense, that would be—that would be as expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have been concerned that the downside risks, though, are, are prevalent now, which are—which are really the risk of the further spread of the disease and also the risk that, that households will run through the savings they’ve managed to accumulate on their balance sheet and that that could weigh on activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But what we see up to the present, really, is, continued growth, continued expansion, but at, at a gradually moderating pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it is—obviously, it’s for Congress to decide the timing, size, and components of further fiscal support for the economy, and I will say that the support provided by the CARES Act was absolutely essential in supporting the recovery that we’ve seen so far, which November 5, 2020 has generally exceeded expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I do think it’s likely that further support is likely to be Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL needed for monetary policy and fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I just mentioned the two risks that I think we, we face, and those would be well addressed through more fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One is the further spread of the virus, and the other is the lapsing of the CARES Act benefits and the savings on people’s balance sheets that will dwindle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I, you know, I think it’s appropriate for us not to try to prescribe for Congress exactly what they should do or what the timing of it should be or what the size of it should be and leave it at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So on your first question, you know, we’ll take into account all external factors and, and do what we think we need to do with the tools that we have to pursue our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we will do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ve said it on a couple of occasions that that will go better and move more quickly if we have a broad set of policies from across the government.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve said this in the very beginning: It’s really, first and foremost, health-care policy, getting the—getting the spread of the virus under control and working on therapeutics and vaccines and that kind of thing, getting—so that—those are absolutely critical to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, those are important, as well as health policies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re, they’re going to be critical to the November 5, 2020 economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Fiscal policy can do what we can’t, which is to replace lost incomes for people who Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL are out of work through no fault of their own.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then we—what we can do is, we can obviously support financial stability through our lending programs, and, and we can support demand through, through interest rates and asset purchases and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, we’re going to take the economy as it comes, including all external factors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think all of us lived through the experience of the—of the years after the Global Financial Crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And for a number of years there, in the middle of the recovery, fiscal policy was pretty tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: and I think I just would say that I think we’ll have a stronger recovery if we can just get at least some more fiscal support when it’s appropriate, you know, when it’s appropriate and in the size Congress thinks is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do think that that will likely—and, by the way, you see, you know, a lot of discussion on both sides of the aisle, on both sides of the Hill that suggests generally that there will be something.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on the first—the first question, it’s—our asset purchases are serving both purchases, both—sorry, both purposes: financial market function and support for economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and that’s really been true—I think in the very beginning of the crisis, November 5, 2020 the main focus was, obviously, financial, financial market function, particularly in, in, you know, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL some of the major markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But after that period, we’ve, we’ve understood all along that our purchases are also supporting economic activity, and that’s important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that need hasn’t dwindled at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, so we haven’t looked at reducing purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So in terms of what they can do, first I would just say, the purchases that we have in place are providing strong support to economic activity still.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, they’re sustaining the gains we’ve made in financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we don’t—we don’t take anything for granted.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we don’t expect that things will deteriorate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, nonetheless, we have a habit of keeping things in place for a while.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re not taking our gains in financial market function for granted, although, admittedly, they’ve been very large.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the asset purchases are just another very important piece of the accommodative policy stance that we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, as you know, these—we’re buying $120 billion a month.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s $1.44 trillion, if I remember my times tables.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s just providing a lot of support for, for economic activity and, by the way, removing just about the same amount of duration risk from private hands as QE3 did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is a big program, and it’s doing a lot of good.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we also, today, you know, we had a full discussion of the options around quantitative ease—not quantitative easing, the asset purchase program, and, you know, we understand the, the ways in which we can adjust the parameters of it to deliver more accommodation if it turns out to be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right now, we think that this very large, effective program is delivering about the right amount of accommodation and support for the markets, and so it continues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you did—you laid out nicely the, the risks of damage to the supply side of the economy, or “scarring,” as you put it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve been talking about those since the very beginning of the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The risk is that, for example, people are out of the labor force for an extended period of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They lose their attachment to the labor force, and it’s harder to get back.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Your skills atrophy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s harder to get back in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the record is, if you don’t get back in very fairly quickly, it can be harder to get back in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that holds down the whole economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, it also—it places enormous burdens on individuals who may have this happen to them at an important stage in their career.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s, it’s, it’s important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know—so that is one of the reasons why our response was so strong and so urgent at the beginning and why we called this, this set of risks out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t know how we could be much more vocal about it than we have been.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Fortunately, for—you know, the economic recovery has exceeded, certainly, the downside cases that we were very concerned about and even, even exceeded—sort of exceeded the baseline expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, that’s so far.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are a long way from our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’re, we’re sort of halfway there on the labor market recovery at best.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and there are parts of the economy where it’s going to be hard until there’s a vaccine—you know, the parts of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, that’s the supply-side damage.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s sort of the third thing that we talk about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The first, at the beginning, it was to provide relief and comfort.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The second—then the second part was to November 5, 2020 provide support when—to the expansion when it came.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the third was to avoid longer-run Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL damage to the economy, and that’s, that’s all of these things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we have been vocal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ll, we’ll try to continue to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and those are—that’s again—that goes to keeping this episode as short as it can be and avoiding unnecessary business bankruptcies, unnecessary household bankruptcies, and unnecessary long-term stays of unemployment or supporting people through them so that they can maintain their financial footing and their lives and be able to go back to work in a productive way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s very important that—you know, there is a real threat here of those things, and, and, you know, we’re trying to do everything we can to minimize that threat.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, first, let me say, we do think that the facilities have, have generally served their purposes well, particularly in supporting the flow of credit, particularly acting as backstops to private markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, overall, we think that the, the programs have, have gone well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the extension, we are, we are just now turning to that question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ve had a lot of things to work our way through.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right now we’re just in the process of turning to that question and, of course, not made any decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in terms of the process, this is a decision that, of course, we have to make and will make jointly with the Treasury Department.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay, thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So two questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the answer to that would be “no,” I don’t think that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think—I think that we are strongly committed to using these powerful tools that we have to support the economy during this difficult time for as long as needed, and no one should have any doubt about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we do not doubt the power of the things that we’ve already done or the things that we may, may do in the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do think there’s more that can be done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I also think, if you look at the stock of assets that we’ve bought, if you look at the facilities and, and the way we’ve been able to keep accommodative financial—financial conditions accommodative, I think we’ve been able to do a lot of things that are November 5, 2020 providing very strong support for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re going to—we’re going to keep Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve said—we’ve said from the very beginning, though, that this is particular—that the particular situation we find ourselves in is one where there is a sudden loss of income on, on the part of millions and tens of millions of people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not so much a typical recession where demand weakens, the Fed cuts interest rates, interest rates stimulate demand, and the economy recovers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a sudden shock where tens of millions of people are out of work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the fiscal response was, was frankly, I think, very good and very robust in the United States.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s certainly one of the main reasons why the recovery has been as good as it’s been so far.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I do think fiscal policy is absolutely essential here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, stimulating aggregate demand is one thing, but where there’s a part of the economy that kind of will be resistant to that, you also need fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, you need health-care policy too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I mentioned in my—in my opening remarks, it’s a concern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have a widespread spike in cases across the country, more in some regions than others.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And even if we don’t have—and I don’t expect that we would—sort of government-imposed restrictions, it does seem likely, though, that people who have maybe begun to engage in activities that they had in flying, staying in a hotel, going to restaurants, going to bars, and, and things like that, that they may pull back in a situation where suddenly the cases are everywhere in your city, your state, your community.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I do think that that’s a risk that we have as we go into the fall now and, and the cases spike.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That, that could weigh on economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One would expect that it would.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We thought the same thing, in fairness, about the wave we had this summer in the South and the West.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the November 5, 2020 economy, you know, seemed to move right through that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This one seems to be larger and more Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL widespread.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In any case, it’s a risk, is what I would characterize it—I would characterize it as a risk, as I did in my—in my comments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me—let me say, in the first instance, our, our main focus is on doing our job, and that is really what we’re, we’re focused on is using the tools that Congress has given us and the assignment they’ve given us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we’re, we’re—that is the thing that we think about night and day.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I just know from, from the experience of the last cycle, it helps to have the whole government working on these things, and this one is particularly that way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, I don’t—I think—you know, I, I don’t want to say whether I feel like I’m being heard or not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, sure, I think there are plenty of people on Capitol Hill who, on both sides of the aisle, on both sides of the Hill, who see a need for further fiscal action and understand perfectly why that might be the case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t really have a specific hypothetical I would—I would put to you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would just say that we, we understand that there are a number of parameters that we have where we can shift the composition, the duration, you know, the size, the life, life cycle of the program.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of those things are, are available to us as ways to deliver addition—you know, more accommodation if we think that’s appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right now, we, we like the amount of accommodation the program is, is delivering.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it will just depend on the—on the facts and circumstances.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We may reach a view at some point that we need to do more on that front.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today’s meeting was about analyzing the—one of the things it was about was about analyzing the various ways and having a, you know, good discussion about how to think about those, those various parameters, which I, I thought was quite a useful discussion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I do think that the public, public will expect and has every right to expect that we—that in our oversight of the financial system, we will account for all material risks and try to protect the economy and the public from those risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Climate change is, is one of those risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a relatively—the science and art of incorporating climate change into our thinking about financial regulation is relatively new, as you know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we are, you know, very actively, in the early stages of this, getting up to speed, working with our central bank colleagues and other colleagues around the world to try to think about how this can be part of our framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re watching what other—what other countries are doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re active participants, as you know, in the CG—no, the greening the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we haven’t, we hadn’t actually formally joined, but we’re there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re in the working groups, and we’re doing all of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re very much working with and monitoring the things other central banks are doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You hear—you know, there’s lots of research going on at the various Reserve Banks and here at the Board in trying to understand this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These tend to be longer-term risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, of course, the longer term does arrive over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we take it as our obligation to—you know, to understand these risks and incorporate them into our—into the way we supervise and, and think about the, the overall financial system and the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on your first question, we, we really are just turning to this issue now, and we have not made any decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we are just getting started on it, and, and it’s a decision that we’ll make jointly with the Treasury Department.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s really all I can say today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s all I have for you on that today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the tail risks, I mean, I think clearly the tail risks that we were worried about have, have subsided.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we were worried about very negative potential outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that—you know, that’s, that’s—what is to be expected of us is, is to think about how things can go wrong as well as the way things that can go right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we, we have to—we do make policy from a risk-management standpoint.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t just look at the most likely case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would not say that anybody’s feeling comfortable about this, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ve gotten through the first five, six months of the—of the expansion better than expected, but we do see in Europe—look what’s happening in Europe, look what’s happening here—another spike in cases as the cold weather arrives and people are inside more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we have to be humble about where we are relative to this—to this disease.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It hasn’t gone away.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Clearly, you know, therapeutics are advancing, research on vaccines are advancing, death rates are way down, hospitalization rates are, are lower now, but—so we’re learning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, I mean, we, we are so—we’re very far from saying that we think we’ve got this and eliminated the tail risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think, clearly, the tail risks have, have diminished since—at least our perception of them has diminished since earlier in the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me say why it’s such an important—you know, in a world where so many payments are made digitally and all that, coins and currency are very important for the relatively low-income people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so it’s a really incredibly important part of the payment system, and we do pay a lot of attention to it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I actually just—I just caught up this morning with the—with the person who heads that operation here who, who says that, yes, things have really gotten significantly better on the coin front.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we worked very hard to increase the supply of coins and, even more than that, the distribution of coins around the System and are happy to say that that situation is well on the way to normalizing itself.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So very pleased to report that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’m very reluctant, as you will imagine, to comment on the election directly, indirectly, at all, other than just to say that it’s a good time to take a step back and let the institutions of our democracy do their jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, at the Fed here, we will, as November 5, 2020 always, continue to do our jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Every day we’ll continue to serve the American people using Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL our tools to support the economy during this difficult time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the—you ask if we had discussions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say, you know, the meeting we just finished, for example, what we do is we talk about the economy and markets, domestically and around the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We hear reports on how households and businesses are doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We talk about risks to the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We talk about what the right policy response might be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the election comes up in some—you know, it comes up now and again, but it is not at all a central focus of the meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I’ll just leave it at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, very reluctant to get into anything more than that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, we have had very little demand below $1 million in loans.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And part of that just is that the fee structure is what it is, and that’s the compensation that the banks get.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there’s a certain amount of work that they have to do to get—to get into the loan program and do—and to document the thing, the loans that they make because these are loans that, you know, go on their balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They keep 5 percent, so they actually have to underwrite the credit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re relying on them, to some extent, for, for doing that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we were reluctant.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We moved the minimum down to $250,000, and we were reluctant to go below that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we heard, over and over again, that it would be great if we could reduce it to $100,000.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and, you know, we’ve been saying we’d have to redesign the program.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, I got the question in a—in an oversight hearing a month or so ago with the Secretary and said that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it—basically, we concluded we could just change the fee structure to create incentives for that, so we did that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We try to be responsive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want, you know, qualifying businesses to be able to borrow.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll see how much demand will come.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We tend to—it’s—there’s more work than one might—certainly than I imagined in setting up one of these facilities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you, you just try to get it out there and get it working and not try to do everything before you start it because you’ll never start it if you do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Then you get it started, and you make changes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve been willing to make changes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s the most recent set of ones that we’ve done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, we hope—we hope that it will help some companies, and I guess we’ll find out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So when I say we’re not out of ammo, I’m looking at, you know, a couple of our tools, mainly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, the asset purchase program—there’s a number of dimensions in which we can adjust that if we deem it to be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right now, we like the job it’s doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We could, you know, if, if the facilities are extended, we could certainly look at November 5, 2020 new facilities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If—you know, if things deteriorate, that would be the case where you’d want to Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL maybe continue the facilities and, and, and maybe change them and maybe have new ones.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, certainly, the facilities have been doing a lot of work and been very successful, I think, overall in accomplishing that job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I do think there, there are things that we can do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, remember, we’ve always said this will take a whole of government approach, including health-care policy and fiscal policy too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it really is, if you—if you want to get the economy back as quickly as possible to where we want it to be, then, then really it should be all of government working together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a bunch of programs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say that the, you know, the corporate—the larger corporate market-based lending program has been very successful without making a single loan—I think, unambiguously, has been a big success.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the success—I think the state and local government program has also restored market function so that—whereas, you know, there were the, the sort of individual investors who wind up funding loans in the muni market through.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: through mutual funds, they, they had withdrawn a lot of money, and, and that—we’ve had many weeks of consecutive, I believe, of, of inflows there, and you’re largely back to a normal functioning market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that’s also been a success.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the other—certainly the, the funding market programs have been a big success.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The—Main Street is just—is just a bigger challenge than all of them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Reaching out to small and medium-sized businesses through the banking system, which we had to do, is, is quite challenging.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do think, you know, the grant programs, the PPP, were, were a great way to reach smaller companies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, what you hear out there is that demand—you talk to banks, and they’ll say demand for loans is very, very low right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Companies are not borrowing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and the reason is that, you know, activity’s at a relatively low level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They don’t want to run up their debt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, so I—we put, we put an awful lot into Main Street, and it is very challenging to reach a lot of those companies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I—you know, I think we, we are reaching many of them now, and, and I hope that the new changes will help us reach more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, so I’m going to take your question literally.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so if the idea is money-financed fiscal policy, that’s not something that we would consider.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that—what I mean by that is, is really, you know, the, the central bank is really funding fiscal activities of the government fairly directly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No, that’s not something we do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have different jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That separation between those jobs is absolutely critical in our system of government.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The—you November 5, 2020 know, the job of taxation and spending goes to people who have stood for election and been Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL elected, and that’s the way it should be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There—they have to be responsible to the electorate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have a specific, you know, job to do with, with a specific set of tools to support maximum employment, stable prices, financial stability, help the payment system, supervise banks—all the things we’re assigned to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we, we, we’re not going to get into financing the government and, and—by the way, when we buy government bonds, we don’t—it doesn’t actually, as you probably know, doesn’t change the amount of government debt outstanding.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We issue a reserve to, to purchase a Treasury security, and that’s just another form—on the consolidated balance sheet of the federal government, that’s just another obligation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You change the—you change the, you know, the nature of the obligation, but not the total quantity of debt that the government has when you do these asset purchase programs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t know exactly what you’re referring to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, to—again, to take your question literally about financing fiscal activity, it’s really not something that we think the central bank should do and, and not something we’re looking at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, we’re doing that with the Municipal Liquidity Facility now, so we’re, we’re buying, you know, with, with our own funds and with the CARES Act funds that, that we’ve gotten through Congress and the Treasury.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re buying municipal securities of up to three years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re doing that now as part of an emergency facility under section 13(3), you know, which has to meet the emergency requirements of exigent circumstances and which is all clearly laid out in the law.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, we’re actually doing that now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I, I see—what that is, from our standpoint, is a rare thing that we do under section 13(3) when regular intermediation in the capital markets or in the banking system has broken down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s no longer working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we step in under 13(3), and we provide liquidity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What turns out to happen is, we announce a program, and the market starts working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we only actually have to do a backstop.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The amount of financing that’s happened in the municipal markets this year is much higher than it was the prior year, and, and we didn’t do it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We did—we’ve done a very small number of, of loans.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But just the fact that we’re there as a backstop seems to—seems to get the private parties to get back together and, and get the market working again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s what 13(3) is for.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not—that shouldn’t be a permanent thing where we’re just another federal financing agency that’s available to direct credit to—you know, to very worthy borrowers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That would be more along the lines of a GSE.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s not what we do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re there to provide emergency liquidity when intermediation has broken down and then to pull back on that when—you know, when—as the markets normalize, we pull back and we put those tools away, as we did after the Global Financial Crisis and as we will here when the time comes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.
